title: How TO - The Spread Operator (...)

metadata.description: Learn about How TO - The Spread Operator (...) with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Learn how to use the three dots operator (...) a.k.a the spread operator in JavaScript.
The Spread Operator
The JavaScript spread operator (
...
) expands 
an iterable (like an array) into more elements.
This allows us to quickly copy all or parts of an existing array into another 
array:
Example
Assign the first and second items from
numbers
to variables and put the rest in an array:
const numbersOne = [1, 2, 3];
const numbersTwo = [4, 5, 6];
const 
  numbersCombined = [...numbersOne, ...numbersTwo];

The spread operator is often used to extract only what's needed from an 
array:
Example
const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const [one, two, ...rest] = 
  numbers;

We can use the spread operator with objects too:
Example
const myVehicle = {
brand: 'Ford',
model: 'Mustang',
color: 'red'
}
const updateMyVehicle = {
type: 'car',
year: 
  2021,
color: 'yellow'
}
const myUpdatedVehicle = {...myVehicle, 
  ...updateMyVehicle}

Notice the properties that did not match were combined, but the property that did match,
color
, was overwritten by the last object that was passed,
updateMyVehicle
. The resulting color is now yellow.
See also
:
JavaScript ES6 Tutorial
.

★
+1

summary: This tutorial covers How TO - The Spread Operator (...) concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use How TO - The Spread Operator (...) effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of How TO - The Spread Operator (...) and how to apply it in your projects.
